text:
Light up an
LED for the first
time
tasks: Obtain an LED and a suitable resistor.
Connect the LED to a power source using the resistor to limit the current.
Ensure the LED lights up without damage.
description: A beginner-friendly activity to light up an LED for the first time.

text:
Learn to
use wire strippers
tasks: Get a pair of wire strippers.
Practice stripping insulation from wires of different gauges.
Avoid damaging the copper core.
description: Learn how to properly strip insulation from wires without damaging them.

text:
Complete
an electronics kit
tasks: Select a beginner-friendly electronics kit.
Follow the included instructions to assemble the kit.
Test the completed circuit to ensure it works.
description: Build your first electronic project by completing a pre-packaged kit.

text: Learn to Solder
tasks: Acquire a soldering iron and solder.
Practice soldering components onto a practice PCB.
Learn to desolder to fix mistakes.
description: Master the essential skill of soldering components for electronics projects.

text:
Learn to use
a breadboard
tasks: Understand the layout and connections of a breadboard.
Practice connecting simple circuits using jumper wires.
Verify circuit operation with a multimeter or LED.
description: Learn how to use a breadboard to build temporary circuits easily.

text:
Get a circuit
wrong and try
again
tasks: Build a simple circuit intentionally with a common mistake (e.g., wrong resistor value).
Identify the issue using troubleshooting techniques.
Fix the mistake and verify proper operation.
description: Learn the value of troubleshooting by intentionally making and correcting a circuit mistake.

text:
Learn Ohm’s
Law
tasks: Understand the relationship V = IR (Voltage = Current x Resistance).
Use a multimeter to measure voltage, current, and resistance in a circuit.
Apply the formula to verify your measurements.
description: Learn the foundational formula that governs electrical circuits: Ohm's Law.

text:
Fix something
something
that’s broken
tasks: Identify a simple broken electronic device.
Diagnose the problem using basic tools like a multimeter.
Repair the device, ensuring functionality is restored.
description: Practice your electronics skills by troubleshooting and fixing a broken device.

text:
Measure
voltage with
a multimeter
tasks: Obtain a digital or analog multimeter.
Measure the voltage across a power source (e.g., battery).
Measure the voltage drop across a component in a circuit.
description: Learn to use a multimeter to measure voltage in circuits.

text:
Learn to
read a schematic
tasks: Study the symbols used in electrical schematics.
Understand the flow of current and components in a simple circuit diagram.
Recreate a circuit on a breadboard using a schematic.
description: Develop the ability to read and interpret electrical schematics to build circuits.

text:
Learn to read
a datasheet
tasks: Select a datasheet for a simple component like a resistor or LED.
Identify key specifications like voltage, current, and pinout.
Use the datasheet information to properly incorporate the component into a circuit.
description: Learn how to interpret datasheets to understand component specifications and use them effectively.

text:
Learn to
control the
brightness of
an LED
tasks: Build a simple circuit using a resistor and LED.
Replace the resistor with a potentiometer to control brightness manually.
Use PWM (Pulse Width Modulation) with an Arduino or microcontroller to control brightness.
description: Explore methods to control LED brightness using resistors, potentiometers, and microcontrollers.

text:
Learn to
desolder a
through hole
component
tasks: Obtain a soldering iron and desoldering tools (wick or pump).
Practice desoldering components from a practice PCB.
Safely remove components without damaging the board.
description: Master the skill of desoldering components to repair or modify circuits.

text:
Make
something that
makes noise
tasks: Use a buzzer or speaker as an output device.
Build a simple circuit to produce sound using a 555 timer or Arduino.
Experiment with frequency and duration to create different tones.
description: Create a simple electronic project that generates sound using a buzzer or speaker.

text:
Turn a
breadboard
circuit into a
schematic
tasks: Assemble a simple circuit on a breadboard.
Use software like Fritzing or a drawing tool to create a schematic.
Compare your schematic to the breadboard to ensure accuracy.
description: Learn how to document a breadboard circuit by translating it into a formal schematic.

text:
Measure
current with a
multimeter
tasks: Learn how to set a multimeter to the current (A) measurement mode.
Measure the current flowing through a simple circuit.
Record the measurements and verify them using Ohm’s Law.
description: Understand how to use a multimeter to measure the flow of current in a circuit.

text:
Make a voltage
divider to lower
the voltage
for a project
tasks: Learn the voltage divider formula: Vout = Vin * (R2 / (R1 + R2)).
Build a voltage divider circuit with resistors.
Verify the output voltage using a multimeter.
description: Learn to create a voltage divider circuit to reduce voltage levels for your projects.

text:
Turn
something
on using
a sensor
tasks: Choose a sensor (e.g., light, motion, or temperature).
Connect the sensor to a microcontroller or circuit.
Write or modify code to activate an output device based on sensor input.
description: Learn how to use a sensor to detect input and control an output in your projects.

text:
Use a diode
to protect your
circuit from
reverse voltages
tasks: Understand how diodes allow current to flow in one direction.
Add a diode to a circuit to protect against reverse polarity.
Test the circuit by applying reverse voltage and observing the protection.
description: Learn to use a diode to prevent damage to your circuit caused by reverse voltages.

text:
Make an
oscillator that
makes noise
tasks: Build an oscillator circuit using a 555 timer or op-amp.
Connect a speaker or piezoelectric element as an output.
Adjust the frequency of the oscillator to create different tones.
description: Create a circuit that generates sound using an oscillator.

text:
Use a relay
to switch
something on at
a higher voltage
tasks: Understand how relays work to control high voltage circuits using low voltage signals.
Connect a relay to a microcontroller or switch.
Use the relay to turn on a device requiring a higher voltage.
description: Learn how to use a relay to control high voltage circuits with a low voltage input.

text:
Make a
capacitor rocket
(too much voltage)
tasks: Learn how capacitors store and release energy.
Charge a capacitor to its limit (under safe conditions).
Release the stored energy to create a 'rocket' effect safely.
description: Explore the energy storage and release properties of capacitors through a fun experiment.

text:
Learn to
solder surface
mount parts
tasks: Obtain a PCB with surface-mount pads and components.
Practice soldering small components using a fine-tip soldering iron or hot air station.
Inspect your work under magnification for quality.
description: Master the skill of soldering surface-mount components for advanced electronics projects.

text:
Use a
555 timer
in a circuit
tasks: Understand the basics of how a 555 timer works.
Build a simple astable circuit to blink an LED.
Experiment with changing resistor and capacitor values to adjust timing.
description: Learn to use a 555 timer IC to create oscillators and timing circuits.

text:
Make a sound
louder with an
amplifier
tasks: Select an amplifier IC or design a simple transistor amplifier circuit.
Connect a low-power audio source to the amplifier.
Test the circuit by connecting a speaker and adjusting the volume.
description: Boost audio signals using an amplifier circuit for louder sound output.

text:
Use
addressable
RGB LEDs in a
project
tasks: Connect an addressable RGB LED strip to a microcontroller.
Use libraries like Adafruit NeoPixel to control colors and animations.
Create a lighting effect or animation with your LEDs.
description: Learn to use addressable RGB LEDs for dynamic lighting effects in projects.

text:
Make a
project
with a
Raspberry Pi
tasks: Install the Raspberry Pi OS on your device.
Connect sensors, actuators, or displays to the GPIO pins.
Program the Raspberry Pi to perform a specific task (e.g., weather station, media center).
description: Create an electronics project using a Raspberry Pi, from hardware setup to software programming.

text:
Let the
smoke out
accidentally
tasks: Learn what caused the failure in your circuit.
Safely disassemble and inspect the damaged components.
Document the lessons learned to avoid repeating the mistake.
description: Understand the common causes of circuit failure and how to troubleshoot them.

text:
Use fritzing
or TinkerCAD
to create a
circuit diagram
tasks: Download and install Fritzing or TinkerCAD.
Replicate a simple breadboard circuit as a digital schematic.
Export or print your circuit diagram for documentation.
description: Learn to use software tools to create clean and professional circuit diagrams.

text:
Make
something
with Arduino
tasks: Choose a simple Arduino project (e.g., blinking LED or temperature sensor).
Write or upload a sketch to the Arduino board.
Test and troubleshoot your project to ensure it works as intended.
description: Build an electronics project using Arduino for control and automation.

text:
Let the smoke
out of an Arduino
accidentally
tasks: Identify what caused the Arduino failure.
Research methods to protect your Arduino (e.g., voltage regulators, fuses).
Replace or repair the Arduino and test again.
description: Understand how to troubleshoot and prevent accidental damage to your Arduino board.

text:
Measure
frequency with a
multimeter
tasks: Understand the frequency measurement mode of your multimeter.
Connect the multimeter to a waveform generator or an AC source.
Record and interpret the frequency reading.
description: Learn to measure signal frequencies using a multimeter equipped with a frequency function.

text:
Use an
Op-Amp  in
a circuit
tasks: Study the basic configurations of Op-Amps (inverting, non-inverting, buffer).
Build a simple amplifier or comparator circuit using an Op-Amp.
Test your circuit and analyze the output.
description: Explore the versatile applications of operational amplifiers in electronics circuits.

text:
Use a crowbar
circuit to protect
against over voltage
tasks: Learn the purpose and operation of a crowbar circuit.
Design and build a crowbar circuit using a thyristor or similar component.
Test the circuit by simulating an overvoltage condition.
description: Design a circuit to protect sensitive electronics from overvoltage conditions.

text:
Use a surge
diode to protect
a circuit
tasks: Learn how surge diodes protect circuits from voltage spikes.
Choose an appropriate diode for your application.
Integrate the surge diode into an existing circuit for protection.
description: Learn how to use diodes to protect electronics from transient voltage spikes.

text:
Make
something
for a friend
tasks: Ask your friend what they need or want as a project.
Design and build a custom electronic gadget or tool for them.
Test the project to ensure it works as expected.
description: Use your skills to create a thoughtful and functional gift for a friend.

text:
Make a motor
controller with
a H Bridge
tasks: Understand the function of an H-Bridge in motor control.
Build an H-Bridge circuit using transistors or an IC (e.g., L298).
Test the circuit by controlling the direction and speed of a DC motor.
description: Learn how to control a motor's speed and direction using an H-Bridge circuit.

text:
Make a
counter with
logic gates
tasks: Learn the basics of digital counters and logic gates.
Design a simple binary counter using logic ICs (e.g., 74LS90).
Test the counter by providing clock pulses and observing the output.
description: Design and build a basic counter circuit using logic gates.

text:
Apply solder
paste to a PCB
with a stencil
tasks: Obtain a PCB stencil for your board.
Secure the PCB and stencil in place.
Apply solder paste evenly and inspect the result under magnification.
description: Learn to apply solder paste for surface-mount components using a stencil.

text:
Teach a
friend an
electronics skill
tasks: Choose a simple electronics skill (e.g., soldering, using a multimeter).
Prepare materials and examples for teaching.
Guide your friend through learning and practicing the skill.
description: Share your knowledge by teaching a friend a useful electronics skill.

text:
Make something
with a 7
segment display
tasks: Understand how to control a 7-segment display (common cathode or anode).
Build a simple circuit to display a number.
Add functionality to increment or decrement the number with a button.
description: Create a project using a 7-segment display to show numerical information.

text:
Measure
voltage with an
oscilloscope
tasks: Learn how to set up an oscilloscope for voltage measurement.
Connect the oscilloscope to a DC and AC source.
Record and interpret the waveforms displayed.
description: Use an oscilloscope to measure and visualize voltage signals.

text:
Measure
capacitor equivalent
series resistance
tasks: Learn the concept of equivalent series resistance (ESR) in capacitors.
Use an ESR meter to measure the resistance of various capacitors.
Compare the ESR of new and aged capacitors.
description: Explore the ESR measurement of capacitors to evaluate their performance.

text:
Make an
Internet of Things
(IoT) project
tasks: Choose a microcontroller with IoT capabilities (e.g., ESP8266, ESP32).
Create a simple project, such as monitoring temperature online.
Deploy and test the project on a local or public network.
description: Build a connected device that communicates over the internet for monitoring or control.

text:
Make
something with
solar panels
tasks: Obtain a small solar panel for your project.
Design a circuit to use solar power for charging or operation.
Test the circuit under different light conditions.
description: Use renewable solar energy to power an electronic project.

text:
Look at an
audio input
on an oscilloscope
tasks: Connect an audio source to the oscilloscope.
Adjust settings to visualize the waveform.
Experiment with different frequencies and amplitudes.
description: Visualize and analyze audio signals using an oscilloscope.

text:
Make a
regulated
power supply
tasks: Learn the basics of voltage regulation.
Build a regulated power supply using a voltage regulator IC (e.g., LM317).
Test the output under different loads.
description: Design a power supply circuit that provides a stable voltage output.

text:
Use a MOSFET
instead of a relay
in a project
tasks: Understand the differences between relays and MOSFETs.
Replace a relay with a MOSFET in an existing circuit.
Test the new circuit for functionality and efficiency.
description: Enhance your project by using a MOSFET as a switching element.

text:
Make your
own
USB cable
tasks: Learn the pinout and specifications of USB connectors.
Cut and solder the required wires to create a custom USB cable.
Test the cable for data and power transfer.
description: Create a custom USB cable for your specific needs or repairs.

text:
Use an LED
matrix in
a project
tasks: Understand how to control an LED matrix with a driver IC or microcontroller.
Design a project that displays patterns or text on the matrix.
Experiment with animations or dynamic outputs.
description: Incorporate an LED matrix to create dynamic visual effects in a project.

text:
Filter
unwanted noise
from a signal
tasks: Learn the basics of low-pass, high-pass, and band-pass filters.
Design and implement a filter circuit to clean up a noisy signal.
Test the circuit with different noise levels and analyze the output.
description: Build a circuit to remove unwanted noise from a signal using filters.

text:
Use a freqency
analyser
for a project
tasks: Learn the functionality of a frequency analyzer.
Connect the analyzer to your project to measure frequency spectra.
Interpret the results to optimize your circuit or design.
description: Utilize a frequency analyzer to understand and refine your project.

text:
Order a
PCB with
your design
tasks: Learn to use PCB design software (e.g., KiCad, Eagle).
Export Gerber files for your design.
Submit the files to a PCB manufacturer and review the finished product.
description: Bring your circuit design to life by creating and ordering a custom PCB.

text:
Repair a
broken trace
on a PCB
tasks: Learn techniques for repairing PCB traces (e.g., using solder or conductive ink).
Identify and repair a damaged trace on a test PCB.
Verify the functionality of the repaired circuit.
description: Fix broken traces on a PCB to restore functionality.

text:
Use
automatic
gain control
tasks: Understand the concept of automatic gain control (AGC).
Design a circuit that adjusts gain automatically using an AGC IC.
Test the circuit with varying input signals.
description: Implement automatic gain control to manage signal levels dynamically.

text:
Make a
PID circuit
with Op-Amps
tasks: Learn the basics of Proportional-Integral-Derivative (PID) control.
Design a PID circuit using Op-Amps for a specific application.
Test and fine-tune the circuit to achieve desired performance.
description: Create a PID control circuit to regulate a system with precision.

text:
Teach a
class on
Electronics
tasks: Prepare a lesson plan on a chosen topic in electronics.
Deliver the class to an audience (friends, students, or peers).
Gather feedback and improve your teaching skills.
description: Share your knowledge of electronics by teaching a class.

text:
Learn
PCB Design
Software
tasks: Install and explore PCB design software such as KiCad or Eagle.
Create a simple circuit design and layout.
Export files and validate them for PCB manufacturing.
description: Gain skills in PCB design by learning to use dedicated software tools.

text:
Use an
e-paper display
in a project
tasks: Learn the working principles of e-paper displays.
Integrate an e-paper display into a microcontroller project.
Create a simple program to update the display with data.
description: Incorporate an e-paper display into your electronics project for a low-power, high-contrast interface.

text:
Build a
Radio Frequency
(RF) Project
tasks: Learn about RF circuits and components.
Design and build a basic RF transmitter or receiver circuit.
Test the project with real-world signals.
description: Create an RF-based project for communication or sensing applications.

text:
Make an
open source
project
tasks: Choose an idea for an open-source electronics project.
Document your design, including schematics and code.
Publish the project on a platform like GitHub with clear instructions.
description: Contribute to the community by creating and sharing an open-source electronics project.

text:
Use capacitive
touch in a PCB
design
tasks: Learn how capacitive touch technology works.
Design a PCB with capacitive touch sensors.
Test the sensors and integrate them into a functional project.
description: Implement capacitive touch technology in your PCB design for an interactive interface.

text:
Make
something
with PCB Art
tasks: Learn about techniques for adding artistic elements to PCBs.
Design a PCB with creative shapes, silkscreen art, or unique layouts.
Order the PCB and assemble the circuit with your design.
description: Combine engineering and art by creating a visually striking PCB design.

text:
Make an
electronic
sculpture
tasks: Design a sculpture that incorporates electronic components.
Build the sculpture using LEDs, sensors, or moving parts.
Showcase the sculpture as a piece of functional art.
description: Create an electronic sculpture that blends technology with art.

text:
Make a switch
mode power
supply
tasks: Learn the principles of switch-mode power supplies (SMPS).
Design and simulate an SMPS circuit.
Build and test the circuit with various loads.
description: Design and build an efficient switch-mode power supply for powering devices.

text:
Release a
tutorial on a
project you've made
tasks: Choose a project you've completed and prepare a detailed write-up.
Create images, diagrams, or videos to support your explanation.
Publish the tutorial on a platform like YouTube, a blog, or Hackaday.
description: Share your knowledge and experience by creating a tutorial for one of your electronics projects.

text:
Create an
FPGA Project
tasks: Learn the basics of FPGA programming and hardware description languages.
Choose an FPGA board and create a simple project (e.g., a blinking LED).
Test and debug your design using simulation tools.
description: Dive into digital design by creating a project with an FPGA.

text:
Write your
own C/C++ library
for a sensor
from scratch
tasks: Choose a sensor and understand its datasheet thoroughly.
Write a library in C or C++ to interface with the sensor.
Test the library in a real project and refine it for reliability.
description: Enhance your programming and hardware skills by developing a custom library for a sensor.
